pullRequest.body:
Port of [mathlib#17140](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/17140) plus much more. Comments therein addressed.

For any continuously differentiable vector field (section of tangent bundle) on a manifold `M` and any chosen interior point `x‚ÇÄ : M`, there exists an integral curve `Œ≥ : ‚Ñù ‚Üí M` such that `Œ≥ t‚ÇÄ = x‚ÇÄ` for any real number `t‚ÇÄ` and the tangent vector of `Œ≥` at `t` coincides with the vector field at `Œ≥ t` for all `t` within an open interval around `t‚ÇÄ`.

As a corollary, such an integral curve exists for any starting point `x‚ÇÄ` if `M` is a manifold without boundary.

We define three `Prop`s:
1. `IsIntegralCurveOn Œ≥ v s` means `Œ≥ t` is tangent to `v (Œ≥ t)` for all `t` within `s : Set ‚Ñù`.
2. `IsIntegralCurveAt Œ≥ v t‚ÇÄ` means `Œ≥` is a local integral curve to `v`. That is, `Œ≥ t` is tangent to `v (Œ≥ t)` for all `t` within some open interval of `t‚ÇÄ`.
3. `IsIntegralCurve Œ≥ v` means `Œ≥` is a global integral curve to `v`. That is, `Œ≥ t` is tangent to `v (Œ≥ t)` for all `t : ‚Ñù`.

Lemmas about rescaling and translation of integral curves are proven:
* If `Œ≥` solves `v` at `t‚ÇÄ`, then `Œ≥ (t + dt)` is tangent to `v` at `t‚ÇÄ - dt`.
* If `Œ≥` solves `v` at `t‚ÇÄ`, then `Œ≥ (a * t)` is tangent to `a ‚Ä¢ v` at `t‚ÇÄ / a` for any non-zero `a`.
* The constant function at `x‚ÇÄ` solves any `v` with `v x‚ÇÄ = 0`.

We also shuffle the position of `‚àÉ Œµ > (0 : ‚Ñù)` in `PicardLindelof` to one that makes more sense, since `f t‚ÇÄ = x‚ÇÄ` does not depend on `Œµ` yet.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>
-->

- [x] depends on: #8624
- [x] depends on: #8672

nodes.body:
(Taking the liberty to tag this as differential geometry; hope you don't mind.)

I think the definition of interior and boundary of a manifold would make a nice little section; would you be interested if I try to flesh that out a little? (For instance, I could push a commit to your PR, or make a separate PR with you as co-author.)

> (Taking the liberty to tag this as differential geometry; hope you don't mind.)
> 
> I think the definition of interior and boundary of a manifold would make a nice little section; would you be interested if I try to flesh that out a little? (For instance, I could push a commit to your PR, or make a separate PR with you as co-author.)

FYI, I started a section outlining these things [on a branch](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/MR-interior-boundary). I think that is close to the right abstraction for mathlib; a number of sorries are still open. If you'd like, we can join forces in filling them in :-).
I‚Äôd love to work together on this. You should just push to my branch! Thanks for all the detailed comments :)

I just pushed a commit with my skeleton for interior and boundary. I'll work a little while more on it (30mins perhaps), then I'll leave it to you. By the way, did you forget to push local changes?

Edit: done for today; feel free to take over!
Yes I did forget to push local changes. Will merge them with your commits!

I've added some detailed comments to the long proof to facilitate simplification. My sense is that it would help to add a few lemmas about changes of coordinates in the tangent bundle, i.e. as derivatives of compositions of charts of the base space.

Added translation and scale lemmas for integral curves:
* If `Œ≥` solves `v` with `Œ≥ t‚ÇÄ = x‚ÇÄ`, then `Œ≥ (t + dt)` solves `v` with `Œ≥ (t‚ÇÄ - dt) = x‚ÇÄ`.
* If `Œ≥` solves `v` with `Œ≥ t‚ÇÄ = x‚ÇÄ`, then `Œ≥ (a * t)` solves `a ‚Ä¢ v` with `Œ≥ (t‚ÇÄ / a) = x‚ÇÄ` for any non-zero `a`.

Just pushed my local changes. Nice that there were almost no conflicts, as we've worked in different files :-)

There was one small conflict: your lemma "IsInteriorPoint" conflicted with the the definition. I renamed it to `is_interior_point` --- per the [naming convention](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html) for mathlib4, it should be named in snake_case.

Your high-level comments on the proof are really helpful! I took another quick skim, see below.

If you're in the mood for a distraction, you're welcome to prove the first lemma `foobar` about interior points. Apart from that, this file is basically complete - I also welcome your comments, ideas and suggestions for improvement there. :-)

I'll be away from mathlib, definitely until the weekend (perhaps one more week).

Reviewing in detail *how* to prove that interior and boundary are disjoint, I realised/remembered
- the usual proofs all require singular homology and something like Banach's fixed point theorem (which has been [formalised](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/Completed.20proof.20of.20the.20Brouwer.20Fixed.20Point.20Theorem/near/297494528), but not yet ported to Lean 4 --- [singular homology](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/335062-homology/topic/Status.20of.20actual.20homology.20theory/near/402058994) is not far, though)
- the proof requires finite-dimensionality
(There are infinite-dimensional generalisations of Brouwer's fixed point theorem, but these require a compact domain. In this context, that's not enough: Banach manifolds are not locally compact in general.)
- As such, I'll move all lemmas relying on this  (e.g.: interior is open, interior and boundary are disjoint) to another PR, which is blocked on these landing. (Or feel free to delete them if you're waiting on me. My Lean time for the next two weeks is up.)

It's sad to "let go"; this was a good run. Yet, none of this is going to *waste* --- just postponed. And next time, I'll read up on the full proof beforehand...

Alas, the little `foobar` is one of those seemingly obvious but totally non-trivial (not correct) theorems. I'd looked into it many months ago, but wasn't sure if there's any generalisation beyond finite-dimension. Thanks for making another PR about that.

I'll be polishing up the main proof in this PR and splitting it off into a few more helper lemmas. Look forward to chatting more after your Lean break.

I believe the tangent bundle API could be much more convenient than it is now. To do coordinate changes, you currently have to go down to the level of `VectorBundleCore` and specify chart choices `achart H x`. Since we'd like to work a lot more with `extChartAt I x`, I suggest a shorthand like:
```
def tangentCoordChange (I) {M} ... (x y : M) := (tangentBundleCore I M).coordChange (achart H x) (achart H y)
```
together with a bunch of helper lemmas about `tangentCoordChange I x x` and compositions of `tangentCoordChange`. These are just elevated versions of `VectorBundleCore` fields, except the hypotheses like `‚àÄ x ‚àà s.baseSet i,` are now `‚àÄ x ‚àà (extChartAt I y).source`.

Perhaps there is a better approach. Just writing this idea down so I don't forget.

I've ripped out the current version of boundary and replaced it by something more basic, moved to a separate PR. I hope that unblocks your work. (Comments over there are welcome; IIUC, mathlib needs more reviewers and anybody can review PRs.)
I believe this PR is now conceptually complete and ready for review.

Good point about local existence. In the future, we probably want three definitions:
1. Local mere existence: integral curve is tangent to the vector field in some unspecified neighbourhood of the starting point.
2. Local existence: integral curve is tangent to the vector field within a specified subset of the reals.
3. Global existence: integral curve is tangent to vector field for all time.

I suggest the following names:
1. `IsIntegralCurveAt`
2. `IsIntegralCurveOn`
3. `IsIntegralCurve`

I'll add some docstring to clarify this.
Thinking about `IsIntegralCurveOn` and `IsIntegralCurve`, I've realised there's no need to include `x‚ÇÄ` in `IsIntegralCurveAt`. I've removed it from the definition.

I've decided to include `IsIntegralCurveOn` and `IsIntegralCurve` to avoid a refactor in the future. `IsIntegralCurveAt` is now defined in terms of `IsIntegralCurveOn`. Translation and scaling lemmas are proven for each of the three definitions. In the future, we anticipate proving the conditions for the global existence of integral curves, which will need `IsIntegralCurve`. The proof will require a construction that uses `IsIntegralCurveOn`.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#8624~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#8672~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
And I just pushed a comment making I in `range_mem_nhds` implicit again: that was an oversight on my side.

:v: winstonyin can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Merging this now, moving on to #8886! If there's disagreement on the last-minute change in `IsIntegralCurveAt`, we can fix it over there.

It's hard to overstate how happy I am that this is getting merged. It's my first new file / new API! I finished the first draft of this over a year ago (before the port began), and the detailed reviews by @grunweg and @ocfnash have been very supportive and encouraging. Thank you!

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7455750312/job/20285304416)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7455750312/job/20285304114)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7455750312/job/20285303746)

A last collection of comments. Looks good from my side (I don't know if the main proof can be simplified; certainly time will tell also).
This has come a long way - thank you for your perseverance.

Thank you both for all this work and for your persistence; it's great to see differential geometry begin to move.

Please apply my suggestions and then feel free to merge.

bors d+

I know this is still work in progress - I still have some comments and suggestions, perhaps they're helpful. As with the other PR: I'm really glad you're working on this! Don't let my number of comments discourage you; rather take that as a sign that I read your code closely :-)

I haven't looked at the big proof in detail yet.

The more I think about this, the more I believe the terminology in this PR is a bit unfortunate: this PR shows the *local* existence of integral curves - not global existence. Informally speaking (which matches e.g. Lee's textbook), an integral curve is a continuously differentiable curve $\gamma\colon (-\epsilon,\epsilon)\to M$ with $\gamma'(t)=v_{\gamma(t)}$ for all $t$. This formalisation considers curves defined on $\mathbb{R}$, using the familiar junk value pattern --- that's fair. But this has the potential to confuse non-experts in Lean (who might believe you just proved *global* existence).

At least, I'd like the documention to be crystal clear that integral curves are defined on $\mathbb{R}$, but are only tangent on some interval. Many places mention this already; I'd suggest a few more
- the docstring of `IsIntegralCurveAt` should also mention this
- how about adding a section "Implementation notes" in the main docstring and mentioning this junk value pattern?
- rename the main theorem to something with local existence?


At the latest when formalising global existence, I expect you'd need a more flexible definition, to encode the time of existence explicitly --- for instance, a predicate "IsIntegralCurveOn" taking a curve, vector field and time interval. I'm fine with this being added later. If you want to add it today, you can it for `isIntegralCurveAt_const` already. 

That said: that's about the only thing left I have to comment. Thank you for all the hard work!

I just re-read everything and pushed a commit cleaning up some small stuff I found.
- I put the translation and scaling lemmas into their own sections.
- I've re-used the variables \gamma and s when stating lemmas.
- I've re-done the line-breaks (see below).

A last collection of comments. Looks good from my side (I don't know if the main proof can be simplified; certainly time will tell also).
This has come a long way - thank you for your perseverance.

Thank you both for all this work and for your persistence; it's great to see differential geometry begin to move.

Please apply my suggestions and then feel free to merge.

bors d+

```suggestion ‚àÉ Œµ > (0 : ‚Ñù), ‚àÉ (Œ≥ : ‚Ñù ‚Üí M), Œ≥ t‚ÇÄ = x‚ÇÄ ‚àß ‚àÄ (t : ‚Ñù), t ‚àà Set.Ioo (t‚ÇÄ - Œµ) (t‚ÇÄ + Œµ) ‚Üí ```
I'd just say "interior point". :-)
wording suggestion: "there exists an integral curve $\gamma : \mathbb{R}\to M$"
how about adding "local existence" as well?

If you want a docstring, how about this?
```suggestion
/-- If M has no boundary, every point is an interior point. -/
lemma ModelWithCorners.Boundaryless.isInteriorPoint
```

This holds more generally for every local homeomorphism.

```/-- If I is boundaryless, every extended local homeomorphism has open target. -/
lemma LocalHomeomorph.extChart_isOpen_target [I.Boundaryless] {e : LocalHomeomorph M H} :
    IsOpen (e.extend I).target := by
  rw [extend_target, I.range_eq_univ, Set.inter_univ]
  exact I.continuous_symm.isOpen_preimage _ e.open_target
  ```
(My suggested name is probably not ideal.) #find_home suggests this should go into SmoothManifoldWithCorners.lean.
Included your lemma. Thanks! I'm keeping it all in one file for now but will move lemmas to other files at the end where appropriate.
As a general comment: mathlib4 style is to indent all lines in a proof by (at least) two spaces, not zero.
Good to have this clarified!
Slight wording suggestion: "/-- For any continuously differentiable vector field `v` on `M` and any chosen interior point `x‚ÇÄ` of `M`, there exists an integral curve ..."
Can you mention the definition `HasIntegralCurveAt` as well? (I've suggested a docstring below.)

A first cut at a docstring, can surely be optimised:
```suggestion
/-- If `v : M ‚Üí TM` is a vector field on `M` and `x : M`, `HasIntegralCurveAt v Œ≥ x‚ÇÄ t‚ÇÄ` means
`Œ≥ : ‚Ñù ‚Üí M` is a differentiable integral curve of `v` with `Œ≥ x‚ÇÄ = t‚ÇÄ. -/
def HasIntegralCurveAt (v : (x : M) ‚Üí TangentSpace I x) (Œ≥ : ‚Ñù ‚Üí M) (x‚ÇÄ : M) (t‚ÇÄ : ‚Ñù) :=
Thinking about this, I find `HasIntegralCurveAt` misleading. How about `IsIntegralCurveAt`?
I like this. I will also shuffle the arguments around: `IsIntegralCurveAt Œ≥ v t‚ÇÄ x‚ÇÄ`.

These comments can be really helpful, it's great that you're adding them!
They're not detailed enough yet for me to follow the proof.
Given all the Set lemmas you're using, `open`ing Set might be a nice minor clean-up.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:

Looking at e.g. `LocalHomeomorph.isOpen_extend_source`, this should also be in the LocalHomeomorph namespace.
When you're polishing things: I'd just inline this lemma now, given it's literally an alias.

I would agree, except that Lean's type checker seems to have trouble uniting `extChartAt I x` with `(chartAt H x).extend I` if I'm inlining, requiring a named argument and another rewrite. Perhaps I'm missing something.
I think normal comments `with --` would suffice here. Not sure if that's in the style guide or just my personal opinion :-)

Just using `/- ... -/` for multiline comments at the moment. I assume a lot of these comments will be shortened / moved elsewhere once we extract a few lemmas from the proof. Eventually let's use `--`.
Didn't think about this in depth yet, but: would this be worth extracting into a separate lemma?
Yes. I suggest adding a few lemmas in `TangentBundle` to make working with `coordChange` more straightforward. Will be away from mathlib for a week or so as it's Thanksgiving over here.
`exact` suffices and IIRC is a tiny bit faster
see above, use `exact`

I think it should be
```suggestion
lemma ModelWithCorners.isInteriorPoint [I.Boundaryless] {x : M} : I.IsInteriorPoint x := by
```
by naming convention, as IsInteriorPoint is atomic.
:bulb: Ah right, per rule 5. Indeed!
Are the lemmas at #8614 useful here? Can they be used to simplify this? (Sorry for the scope creep.)
Probably some variant of those lemmas, yes, but I'm going to avoid the scope creep for now. The `HasMFDerivAt` API can also use some extra helpful lemmas about simple operations. For another day.

```suggestion
variable (t‚ÇÄ) in
/-- If the vector field `v` vanishes at `x‚ÇÄ`, the constant curve at `x‚ÇÄ`
  is an integral curve of `v`. -/

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion IsIntegralCurveOn Œ≥ v s := fun t _ => h t ```

I've moved the variables here: they're not used in the definition; this makes this clearer.
I don't feel strongly about this particular change.

I think this spelling is slightly more readable: a "new idea" goes on one line (e.g., lemma name, hypothesis, conclusion, proof --- if shorter, they can of course be combined; in this case, as the conclusion doesn't fit on one line anyway, I'd rather put it separately). Again, this is a really minor change.

I have the nagging feeling the next four lemmas could be golfed (all the manipulations around multiplication and division). I might be wrong; perhaps none of  simp, ring and (g)congr is useful here. It might be worth extracting an MWE and asking the hive mind on zulip.

Minor simplification:
```suggestion
    IsIntegralCurveOn Œ≥ v (s ‚à™ s') := fun _ ‚Ü¶ fun | .inl ht => h _ ht | .inr ht => h' _ ht
```

We can clean things up visually a fair bit just by defining `x‚Çú := Œ≥ t`, at the cost of a `dsimp only` later on:
```suggestion
  let x‚Çú : M := (extChartAt I x‚ÇÄ).symm (f t) -- `x‚Çú := Œ≥ t`
  have h : HasDerivAt f (x := t) <| fderivWithin ‚Ñù
      (extChartAt I x‚ÇÄ ‚àò (extChartAt I x‚Çú).symm)
      (range I)
      (extChartAt I x‚Çú x‚Çú)
      (v x‚Çú) :=
    (haux t ht).1
  rw [‚Üê tangentCoordChange_def] at h
  have hf3 := mem_preimage.mp <| mem_of_mem_nhds (haux t ht).2
  have hf3' := mem_of_mem_of_subset hf3 interior_subset
  have hft1 := mem_preimage.mp <|
    mem_of_mem_of_subset hf3' (extChartAt I x‚ÇÄ).target_subset_preimage_source
  have hft2 := mem_extChartAt_source I x‚Çú
  -- express the derivative of the integral curve in the local chart
  refine ‚ü®(continuousAt_extChartAt_symm'' _ _ hf3').comp h.continuousAt,
    HasDerivWithinAt.hasFDerivWithinAt ?_‚ü©
  simp only [mfld_simps, hasDerivWithinAt_univ]
  show HasDerivAt ((extChartAt I x‚Çú ‚àò (extChartAt I x‚ÇÄ).symm) ‚àò f) (v x‚Çú) t
  -- express `v (Œ≥ t)` as `D‚Åª¬π D (v (Œ≥ t))`, where `D` is a change of coordinates, so we can use
  -- `HasFDerivAt.comp_hasDerivAt` on `h`
  rw [‚Üê tangentCoordChange_self (I := I) (x := x‚Çú) (z := x‚Çú) (v := v x‚Çú) hft2,
    ‚Üê tangentCoordChange_comp (x := x‚ÇÄ) ‚ü®‚ü®hft2, hft1‚ü©, hft2‚ü©]
  apply HasFDerivAt.comp_hasDerivAt _ _ h
  apply HasFDerivWithinAt.hasFDerivAt (s := range I) _ <|
    mem_nhds_iff.mpr ‚ü®interior (extChartAt I x‚ÇÄ).target,
      subset_trans interior_subset (extChartAt_target_subset_range ..),
      isOpen_interior, hf3‚ü©
  dsimp only [x‚Çú]
```

(style; my personal taste is to not have more than 2 parentheses in a row! I don't feel very strongly about, it, though, and I don't think there's any convention anywhere, so if you dislike `<|` feel free to change it back üòÖ)
```suggestion
  ‚àÄ t ‚àà s, HasMFDerivAt ùìò(‚Ñù, ‚Ñù) I Œ≥ t ((1 : ‚Ñù ‚ÜíL[‚Ñù] ‚Ñù).smulRight <| v (Œ≥ t))
```

This is a lot of repetition in this paragraph. How about:
```suggestion
Standard ODE existence results imply that a unique local integral curve exists for any continuously
differentiable vector field `v`.
```

```suggestion
 * `IsIntegralCurve Œ≥ v`: `Œ≥ t` is tangent to `v (Œ≥ t)` for all `t : ‚Ñù`. That is, `Œ≥` is a global
integral curve of `v`.
 * `IsIntegralCurveOn Œ≥ v s`: `Œ≥ t` is tangent to `v (Œ≥ t)` for all `t ‚àà s`, where `s : Set ‚Ñù`.
 * `IsIntegralCurveAt Œ≥ v t‚ÇÄ`: `Œ≥ t` is tangent to `v (Œ≥ t)` for all `t` in some open interval
```

```suggestion
 * `exists_isIntegralCurveAt_of_contMDiffAt_boundaryless`: local existence of integral curves for
 C¬π vector fields.
```

```suggestion
## Main definitions / results:
```

Nitpick but we usually use this spelling:
```suggestion
manifold requires special treatment, and we leave it as a TODO.
```

```

If you add this then you can use the notation `ùìù` for `nhds`

open scoped Manifold Topology
```

  ‚àÉ s ‚àà ùìù t, IsIntegralCurveOn Œ≥ v s
```
Likewise at least two other instances below

```suggestion
## Main definitions

No need to change this just yet: but if you gain further results in future PRs, it seems useful to add a proper "Main results" section. (A top-level comment "the local existence and uniqueness of integral curves follows from the existence and uniqueness of solutions to ODEs" still feels useful.)
uniqueness not yet :-)
Small tweak: "if $\gamma\colon\mathbb{R}\to M$ is C¬π on $s\subset\mathbb{R}$ and `v...` is a vector field on M"
How about "open interval containing t_0"? (Same for the other definitions below.)

I would also completely excise the sentence:
```
That is, there exists `Œµ > 0` such that `Œ≥ t` is tangent to `v (Œ≥ t)` for all `t ‚àà Ioo (t‚ÇÄ - Œµ) (t‚ÇÄ + Œµ).
```
The definition is for `nhds`, not intervals, so I've changed the text to say neighbourhood instead.

```suggestion
/-- `Œ≥` is an integral curve for `v` at `t‚ÇÄ` iff
  `Œ≥` is an integral curve on some interval containing `t‚ÇÄ`. -/
lemma isIntegralCurveAt_iff :

```suggestion
/-- If `Œ≥` is an integral curve at each `t ‚àà s`, it is an integral curve on `s`. -/
lemma IsIntegralCurveAt.isIntegralCurveOn (h : ‚àÄ t ‚àà s, IsIntegralCurveAt Œ≥ v t) :
Do you think an iff version of the above lemma would be useful? (If yes, feel free to add it.)
Added!
`by positivity` will also solve the second argument

```suggestion
/-- For any continuously differentiable vector field on `M` and any interior point `x‚ÇÄ ‚ààM`,

It looks like none of these are used
```suggestion
```

To make it really obvious to the casual reader:
```suggestion
def IsIntegralCurveOn (Œ≥ : ‚Ñù ‚Üí M) (v : (x : M) ‚Üí TangentSpace I x) (s : Set ‚Ñù) : Prop :=
```
likewise `IsIntegralCurveAt` and `IsIntegralCurve`.

Can we add this lemma (which I would have been tempted to make the base definition):
```suggestion
lemma IsIntegralCurveAt_iff_eventually :
    IsIntegralCurveAt Œ≥ v t‚ÇÄ ‚Üî
    ‚àÄ·∂† t in ùìù t‚ÇÄ, HasMFDerivAt ùìò(‚Ñù, ‚Ñù) I Œ≥ t ((1 : ‚Ñù ‚ÜíL[‚Ñù] ‚Ñù).smulRight <| v (Œ≥ t)) := by
  rw [Filter.eventually_iff_exists_mem]
  exact ‚ü®id, id‚ü©
```

I changed the base definition of `IsIntegralCurveAt` to use `Filter.Eventually`. See [this commit](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/8483/commits/db893bd366188878c07257b52b6ae47e5ebe5856). This makes the definitions more "symmetric", but also adds a few calls to `isIntegralCurveAt_iff` or `isIntegralCurveAt_iff'` throughout later proofs. If this looks good, I'll merge in a few hours.

Using the lemma suggested above:
```suggestion
  rw [IsIntegralCurveAt_iff_eventually, Metric.eventually_nhds_iff_ball]; rfl
```

Optional: I slightly prefer
```suggestion
  convert hŒ≥.comp_add (-dt)
  ext
  simp only [Function.comp_apply, neg_add_cancel_right, Set.ext_iff]
  aesop
```
similar remarks apply to lemmas below

```suggestion
    ‚àÉ Œ≥ : ‚Ñù ‚Üí M, Œ≥ t‚ÇÄ = x‚ÇÄ ‚àß IsIntegralCurveAt Œ≥ v t‚ÇÄ := by
```

```suggestion
  rw [‚Üê (extChartAt I x‚ÇÄ).right_inv hf3']
  exact hasFDerivWithinAt_tangentCoordChange ‚ü®hft1, hft2‚ü©
```

```suggestion
    ‚àÉ Œ≥ : ‚Ñù ‚Üí M, Œ≥ t‚ÇÄ = x‚ÇÄ ‚àß IsIntegralCurveAt Œ≥ v t‚ÇÄ :=
```

```suggestion
/-- Existence of local integral curves for a C¬π vector field on a smooth manifold without boundary.
-/
```

IMHO this comment is no easier to read than the formal statement. I suggest:
```suggestion
/-- Existence of local integral curves for a C¬π vector field at interior points of a smooth
manifold. -/
```
since the formal statement is available if someone wants more precision.
This is now stated in terms of `Filter.Eventually` to make the three definitions more symmetric.
The lemma @ocfnash suggested above, before I changed the definition of `IsIntegralCurveAt`.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: local existence of integral curves of vector field

nodes.body:
I know this is still work in progress - I still have some comments and suggestions, perhaps they're helpful. As with the other PR: I'm really glad you're working on this! Don't let my number of comments discourage you; rather take that as a sign that I read your code closely :-)

I haven't looked at the big proof in detail yet.

(Taking the liberty to tag this as differential geometry; hope you don't mind.)

I think the definition of interior and boundary of a manifold would make a nice little section; would you be interested if I try to flesh that out a little? (For instance, I could push a commit to your PR, or make a separate PR with you as co-author.)

> (Taking the liberty to tag this as differential geometry; hope you don't mind.)
> 
> I think the definition of interior and boundary of a manifold would make a nice little section; would you be interested if I try to flesh that out a little? (For instance, I could push a commit to your PR, or make a separate PR with you as co-author.)

FYI, I started a section outlining these things [on a branch](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/MR-interior-boundary). I think that is close to the right abstraction for mathlib; a number of sorries are still open. If you'd like, we can join forces in filling them in :-).
I‚Äôd love to work together on this. You should just push to my branch! Thanks for all the detailed comments :)

I just pushed a commit with my skeleton for interior and boundary. I'll work a little while more on it (30mins perhaps), then I'll leave it to you. By the way, did you forget to push local changes?

Edit: done for today; feel free to take over!
Yes I did forget to push local changes. Will merge them with your commits!

I've added some detailed comments to the long proof to facilitate simplification. My sense is that it would help to add a few lemmas about changes of coordinates in the tangent bundle, i.e. as derivatives of compositions of charts of the base space.

Added translation and scale lemmas for integral curves:
* If `Œ≥` solves `v` with `Œ≥ t‚ÇÄ = x‚ÇÄ`, then `Œ≥ (t + dt)` solves `v` with `Œ≥ (t‚ÇÄ - dt) = x‚ÇÄ`.
* If `Œ≥` solves `v` with `Œ≥ t‚ÇÄ = x‚ÇÄ`, then `Œ≥ (a * t)` solves `a ‚Ä¢ v` with `Œ≥ (t‚ÇÄ / a) = x‚ÇÄ` for any non-zero `a`.

Just pushed my local changes. Nice that there were almost no conflicts, as we've worked in different files :-)

There was one small conflict: your lemma "IsInteriorPoint" conflicted with the the definition. I renamed it to `is_interior_point` --- per the [naming convention](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/naming.html) for mathlib4, it should be named in snake_case.

Your high-level comments on the proof are really helpful! I took another quick skim, see below.

If you're in the mood for a distraction, you're welcome to prove the first lemma `foobar` about interior points. Apart from that, this file is basically complete - I also welcome your comments, ideas and suggestions for improvement there. :-)

I'll be away from mathlib, definitely until the weekend (perhaps one more week).

Reviewing in detail *how* to prove that interior and boundary are disjoint, I realised/remembered
- the usual proofs all require singular homology and something like Banach's fixed point theorem (which has been [formalised](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/Completed.20proof.20of.20the.20Brouwer.20Fixed.20Point.20Theorem/near/297494528), but not yet ported to Lean 4 --- [singular homology](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/335062-homology/topic/Status.20of.20actual.20homology.20theory/near/402058994) is not far, though)
- the proof requires finite-dimensionality
(There are infinite-dimensional generalisations of Brouwer's fixed point theorem, but these require a compact domain. In this context, that's not enough: Banach manifolds are not locally compact in general.)
- As such, I'll move all lemmas relying on this  (e.g.: interior is open, interior and boundary are disjoint) to another PR, which is blocked on these landing. (Or feel free to delete them if you're waiting on me. My Lean time for the next two weeks is up.)

It's sad to "let go"; this was a good run. Yet, none of this is going to *waste* --- just postponed. And next time, I'll read up on the full proof beforehand...

Alas, the little `foobar` is one of those seemingly obvious but totally non-trivial (not correct) theorems. I'd looked into it many months ago, but wasn't sure if there's any generalisation beyond finite-dimension. Thanks for making another PR about that.

I'll be polishing up the main proof in this PR and splitting it off into a few more helper lemmas. Look forward to chatting more after your Lean break.

I believe the tangent bundle API could be much more convenient than it is now. To do coordinate changes, you currently have to go down to the level of `VectorBundleCore` and specify chart choices `achart H x`. Since we'd like to work a lot more with `extChartAt I x`, I suggest a shorthand like:
```
def tangentCoordChange (I) {M} ... (x y : M) := (tangentBundleCore I M).coordChange (achart H x) (achart H y)
```
together with a bunch of helper lemmas about `tangentCoordChange I x x` and compositions of `tangentCoordChange`. These are just elevated versions of `VectorBundleCore` fields, except the hypotheses like `‚àÄ x ‚àà s.baseSet i,` are now `‚àÄ x ‚àà (extChartAt I y).source`.

Perhaps there is a better approach. Just writing this idea down so I don't forget.

I've ripped out the current version of boundary and replaced it by something more basic, moved to a separate PR. I hope that unblocks your work. (Comments over there are welcome; IIUC, mathlib needs more reviewers and anybody can review PRs.)
I believe this PR is now conceptually complete and ready for review.

The more I think about this, the more I believe the terminology in this PR is a bit unfortunate: this PR shows the *local* existence of integral curves - not global existence. Informally speaking (which matches e.g. Lee's textbook), an integral curve is a continuously differentiable curve $\gamma\colon (-\epsilon,\epsilon)\to M$ with $\gamma'(t)=v_{\gamma(t)}$ for all $t$. This formalisation considers curves defined on $\mathbb{R}$, using the familiar junk value pattern --- that's fair. But this has the potential to confuse non-experts in Lean (who might believe you just proved *global* existence).

At least, I'd like the documention to be crystal clear that integral curves are defined on $\mathbb{R}$, but are only tangent on some interval. Many places mention this already; I'd suggest a few more
- the docstring of `IsIntegralCurveAt` should also mention this
- how about adding a section "Implementation notes" in the main docstring and mentioning this junk value pattern?
- rename the main theorem to something with local existence?


At the latest when formalising global existence, I expect you'd need a more flexible definition, to encode the time of existence explicitly --- for instance, a predicate "IsIntegralCurveOn" taking a curve, vector field and time interval. I'm fine with this being added later. If you want to add it today, you can it for `isIntegralCurveAt_const` already. 

That said: that's about the only thing left I have to comment. Thank you for all the hard work!

Good point about local existence. In the future, we probably want three definitions:
1. Local mere existence: integral curve is tangent to the vector field in some unspecified neighbourhood of the starting point.
2. Local existence: integral curve is tangent to the vector field within a specified subset of the reals.
3. Global existence: integral curve is tangent to vector field for all time.

I suggest the following names:
1. `IsIntegralCurveAt`
2. `IsIntegralCurveOn`
3. `IsIntegralCurve`

I'll add some docstring to clarify this.
Thinking about `IsIntegralCurveOn` and `IsIntegralCurve`, I've realised there's no need to include `x‚ÇÄ` in `IsIntegralCurveAt`. I've removed it from the definition.

I've decided to include `IsIntegralCurveOn` and `IsIntegralCurve` to avoid a refactor in the future. `IsIntegralCurveAt` is now defined in terms of `IsIntegralCurveOn`. Translation and scaling lemmas are proven for each of the three definitions. In the future, we anticipate proving the conditions for the global existence of integral curves, which will need `IsIntegralCurve`. The proof will require a construction that uses `IsIntegralCurveOn`.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: uniqueness of integral curves of a vector field on a manifold

nodes.body:
I just re-read everything and pushed a commit cleaning up some small stuff I found.
- I put the translation and scaling lemmas into their own sections.
- I've re-used the variables \gamma and s when stating lemmas.
- I've re-done the line-breaks (see below).

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#8624~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#8672~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

A last collection of comments. Looks good from my side (I don't know if the main proof can be simplified; certainly time will tell also).
This has come a long way - thank you for your perseverance.
And I just pushed a comment making I in `range_mem_nhds` implicit again: that was an oversight on my side.

Thank you both for all this work and for your persistence; it's great to see differential geometry begin to move.

Please apply my suggestions and then feel free to merge.

bors d+

:v: winstonyin can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Merging this now, moving on to #8886! If there's disagreement on the last-minute change in `IsIntegralCurveAt`, we can fix it over there.

It's hard to overstate how happy I am that this is getting merged. It's my first new file / new API! I finished the first draft of this over a year ago (before the port began), and the detailed reviews by @grunweg and @ocfnash have been very supportive and encouraging. Thank you!

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7455750312/job/20285304416)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7455750312/job/20285304114)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7455750312/job/20285303746)
